												Rome's Legacy wasn’t built in a day, and the game that bears its namesake was not free from this either. Unlike the empire, however, Rome the game's glory was ripped from it in a single moment---Rome 2's release. For nearly a decade, we the true lovers of Rome awaited its fable return, and begged the gods of the Creative assembly to return to us our legions! After the wonderful gift of Shogun 2 we thought certainly that this would be given to us, and that it would be glorious. Now that all the other classics had been given sequels the greatest of them all certainly was overdue for a revisit. Rome 2 was not a Total War, but a Total Joke... Unless you count the design choices conflicting with your desire to enjoy pillaging all of Antiquity-- But that was about as much a war as the British fighting the Zulu; the Zulu being your enjoyment.This prompted me to return to the original. Was it hard to put aside my Nostalgia to write this review? I would have to say nostalgia had no place in my experience with this game. For as many hours as I put in it all those years ago I can't say I had a plethora of memories to go on. Once I conquered Europe as the Saxons, and once I pitted Carthage against Egypt and both full stack armies were obliterated in an epic stalemate. These were my two favorite memories going into the game.I started up Rome and went for the Expansion "Barbarian Invasion" first. I picked the faction I always played as back in the day and took on the Vandal horde. We marched south into the Baltics and settled in present day Croatia area. Eventually the ERE decided I wasn't fit to exist and attempted a Reconquista. A fifty-year war ensued where we engaged the enemy professional armies with our militia. Suffering through the great losses of our people we pushed south taking Thessalonica and Achaea. The war finally came to a close after the third Siege of Constantinople took the city, and destroyed the ERE's last European Legion, and subjugated the most powerful city in the world during this point in history.The fledgling Vandal Kingdom of the Baltics established and independence now secure I reset the clock (And the game) to play the Vanilla. I decided to go a different route than I did when I was younger. Instead of picking Carthagians, or Scipii; I picked the Brutii. It took me a total of 6 minutes to realize what I just did. I was playing the Roman faction that was tasked to take the same exact lands as my Vandal kingdom had taken in the Expansion. I was essentially building the same ERE I would invade centuries later as the Vandals.  As I am still in the middle of my conquest of the Greek-Macedonian Alliance, I can’t really say that I curb-stomped them... In fact Athens remains defiant and un-siegeable from a practical standpoint. While the Greek armies of Athens  send every one of my Legions home completely rekt, the Macedonians force our defending armies to either remain garrisoned, or all-together abandon settlements to defend more critical points against the armies of the sons of Alexander at our gates.... Eh, at least the Senate likes me.So obviously I enjoy the game. I knew that before I even re-bought it on steam the other day. Despite being a decade old the game gets a ten for just the enjoyment. But I'm so confident in this game I am going to take it the extra mile and rate it like it was released a month ago, and compare it directly to Rome 2.Pros--Competent AISo the AI will not be winning any genius competitions, but put Rome’s AI up against Rome 2's AI and it will mop the floor with Rome II's pretty-boy face. Not only does this apply to the battles but the Campaign AI will actually give the player legitimate trouble.-SoundtrackGood, solid, mood setting music that changes based on the situation.  This music will get you PUMPED, and you'll remember these tracks for a lifetime. The track number is a little lacking in quantity, but quality is perfect. Medieval 2 might be the only one that can beat it.Units-The Roman factions all have the same units just painted different colors, but the Foreign factions are all unique to some extent. And don't think any faction is left out. Each one has their own death machines. Carthage has elephants, Egypt and Britain have Chariots, Greeks and Macedonians have Hoplites-- All of which will thoroughly ruin your day with brutal efficiency. The Barbarian Expansion scores a little lower on this to me, But the expansion still gets clearance on this issueReligion-(Barbarian Invasion only)This is a very simple religion system where the player can convert to a new religion at any point. Ironically the people will convert much, much faster than the player's own royal family. In short it's simple, but works.Engine- This Engine was designed for this type of game; Rome II's was designed for EMPIRE's Ranged based combat. Though the clashes can be anti-climactic at times; you'll never get the ridiculous mosh pit of Shogun 2 and Rome 2. Animations are also nothing to write home about, but they function, and don't jump around for kill animations.General Speeches-Yes. THIS IS HOW YOU DO GENERAL SPEECHES PEOPLE.Cons- Graphics- Graphics are dated, but it's a decade old; Since I said I was Rating this as if it was last month I can't not count this...... ummm.... come on that can't be it...Diplomacy- All total war games fail here, it functions but the AI can act a fool on a regular basis. the only TW game with decent diplomacy is probably Shogun 2.Seriously there’s not much to find wrong with this game. If you like Grand-Strategy and/or RTS this game is the one for you. Is it my favorite Total War game? Um, no I can't say it's my favorite, but it is the original champion. It didn't earn that honor form being a PoS. It was the first one I played back a decade ago, and it echoes a long forgotten day that CA had more pride, love, and passion for this title. Back then it was their baby, and it shows.for $9.99 Rome and the expansion is an investment any lover of strategy will not regret.If it was released last month:Modern Day Score- 7/10Overall and timeframes aside:Final Verdict- 8/10 When all is said and done Rome has aged moderatley well. While it does show it's age; the old man it more than capable of holding it's own and even going toe-to-toe with modern titles. It is the Jack of all trades, but a master of none. It is and forever will be one of my favorites.

												ROMANES EUNT DOMUS?!Rome: Total War is what you play when you want to tell the Romans to go home, or vice versa.It's the third game in the Total War series, and the first to introduce the gameplay template it still uses today. Gone are the 2D battlefield models and Risk-style campaign map from the first two games, replaced with 3D models and a strategic map you can use to finely position units and armies. Gameplay revolves around managing your territory in a turn-based strategy mode and moving armies around the map to fight opposing armies and capture or defend settlements in a real time tactics mode.This particular entry is widely regarded as a classic, and with great value to boot. It can certainly suffice for people who can't afford or run the later games in the series. Unfortunately the game is optimized to run on only one CPU core, so newer computers might run into some trouble anyway. As this is still only the third game in the series, there are some things in later titles that are lacking in this one such as resolutions above 1600x1400. Something to keep in mind, at least.The Gold Edition comes with the Barbarian Invasion expansion that takes place during the fall of the Roman Empire, adding new factions and some new features such as hordes & religion; well worth playing after the base game. There's also a second expansion-slash-DLC available separately that lets you play as Alexander the Great, and it's required for some of the more popular mods to run.The vanilla game is a good way to get the hang of things, but from the disorganized battle lines to the historical inaccuracy I wouldn't recommend playing for any extended period of time. To wit: the Greek city-states form one faction (just one) while Rome is divided into three gens that each get their own faction. Egypt, meanwhile, looks like it walked out of a timewarp from 1000 BC instead of the Ptolemaic empire it was at the time of Rome's ascent.There's a number of mods that overhaul the game to fix these issues and more, including (nominally) improved AI, which has always been a weakpoint of the TW series - with the exception of the first two games, which used Risk-style troop movement that's easier for AI to understand. Two of the most popular RTW mods include Rome Total Realism and Europa Barbarorum, the former being a general overhaul of the game and the latter being much more realism-focused to the point of near simulation.I'd recommend this as an entry point into Total War for people on a budget. It's probably better than Rome II at any rate; even with the many improvements that game's had since its disastrous launch it's still a game about ancient warfare that uses an engine Creative Assembly intended for Napoleonic warfare.

												Rome's Legacy wasn’t built in a day, and the game that bears its namesake was not free from this either. Unlike the empire, however, Rome the game's glory was ripped from it in a single moment---Rome 2's release. For nearly a decade, we the true lovers of Rome awaited its fable return, and begged the gods of the Creative assembly to return to us our legions! After the wonderful gift of Shogun 2 we thought certainly that this would be given to us, and that it would be glorious. Now that all the other classics had been given sequels the greatest of them all certainly was overdue for a revisit. Rome 2 was not a Total War, but a Total Joke... Unless you count the design choices conflicting with your desire to enjoy pillaging all of Antiquity-- But that was about as much a war as the British fighting the Zulu; the Zulu being your enjoyment.This prompted me to return to the original. Was it hard to put aside my Nostalgia to write this review? I would have to say nostalgia had no place in my experience with this game. For as many hours as I put in it all those years ago I can't say I had a plethora of memories to go on. Once I conquered Europe as the Saxons, and once I pitted Carthage against Egypt and both full stack armies were obliterated in an epic stalemate. These were my two favorite memories going into the game.I started up Rome and went for the Expansion "Barbarian Invasion" first. I picked the faction I always played as back in the day and took on the Vandal horde. We marched south into the Baltics and settled in present day Croatia area. Eventually the ERE decided I wasn't fit to exist and attempted a Reconquista. A fifty-year war ensued where we engaged the enemy professional armies with our militia. Suffering through the great losses of our people we pushed south taking Thessalonica and Achaea. The war finally came to a close after the third Siege of Constantinople took the city, and destroyed the ERE's last European Legion, and subjugated the most powerful city in the world during this point in history.The fledgling Vandal Kingdom of the Baltics established and independence now secure I reset the clock (And the game) to play the Vanilla. I decided to go a different route than I did when I was younger. Instead of picking Carthagians, or Scipii; I picked the Brutii. It took me a total of 6 minutes to realize what I just did. I was playing the Roman faction that was tasked to take the same exact lands as my Vandal kingdom had taken in the Expansion. I was essentially building the same ERE I would invade centuries later as the Vandals.  As I am still in the middle of my conquest of the Greek-Macedonian Alliance, I can’t really say that I curb-stomped them... In fact Athens remains defiant and un-siegeable from a practical standpoint. While the Greek armies of Athens  send every one of my Legions home completely rekt, the Macedonians force our defending armies to either remain garrisoned, or all-together abandon settlements to defend more critical points against the armies of the sons of Alexander at our gates.... Eh, at least the Senate likes me.So obviously I enjoy the game. I knew that before I even re-bought it on steam the other day. Despite being a decade old the game gets a ten for just the enjoyment. But I'm so confident in this game I am going to take it the extra mile and rate it like it was released a month ago, and compare it directly to Rome 2.Pros--Competent AISo the AI will not be winning any genius competitions, but put Rome’s AI up against Rome 2's AI and it will mop the floor with Rome II's pretty-boy face. Not only does this apply to the battles but the Campaign AI will actually give the player legitimate trouble.-SoundtrackGood, solid, mood setting music that changes based on the situation.  This music will get you PUMPED, and you'll remember these tracks for a lifetime. The track number is a little lacking in quantity, but quality is perfect. Medieval 2 might be the only one that can beat it.Units-The Roman factions all have the same units just painted different colors, but the Foreign factions are all unique to some extent. And don't think any faction is left out. Each one has their own death machines. Carthage has elephants, Egypt and Britain have Chariots, Greeks and Macedonians have Hoplites-- All of which will thoroughly ruin your day with brutal efficiency. The Barbarian Expansion scores a little lower on this to me, But the expansion still gets clearance on this issueReligion-(Barbarian Invasion only)This is a very simple religion system where the player can convert to a new religion at any point. Ironically the people will convert much, much faster than the player's own royal family. In short it's simple, but works.Engine- This Engine was designed for this type of game; Rome II's was designed for EMPIRE's Ranged based combat. Though the clashes can be anti-climactic at times; you'll never get the ridiculous mosh pit of Shogun 2 and Rome 2. Animations are also nothing to write home about, but they function, and don't jump around for kill animations.General Speeches-Yes. THIS IS HOW YOU DO GENERAL SPEECHES PEOPLE.Cons- Graphics- Graphics are dated, but it's a decade old; Since I said I was Rating this as if it was last month I can't not count this...... ummm.... come on that can't be it...Diplomacy- All total war games fail here, it functions but the AI can act a fool on a regular basis. the only TW game with decent diplomacy is probably Shogun 2.Seriously there’s not much to find wrong with this game. If you like Grand-Strategy and/or RTS this game is the one for you. Is it my favorite Total War game? Um, no I can't say it's my favorite, but it is the original champion. It didn't earn that honor form being a PoS. It was the first one I played back a decade ago, and it echoes a long forgotten day that CA had more pride, love, and passion for this title. Back then it was their baby, and it shows.for $9.99 Rome and the expansion is an investment any lover of strategy will not regret.If it was released last month:Modern Day Score- 7/10Overall and timeframes aside:Final Verdict- 8/10 When all is said and done Rome has aged moderatley well. While it does show it's age; the old man it more than capable of holding it's own and even going toe-to-toe with modern titles. It is the Jack of all trades, but a master of none. It is and forever will be one of my favorites.

												This game is on my Top 5 Games of All Time List.Let's start with the presentation. This Games graphics are out dated, but the attention to detail and polish are abundant. Nothing was more satisfying then watching my cavalry charge send individual men flying. The world map is kind of bland, but you have a pretty good idea of what the terrain is. All of the cities are (or were) real cities, and many you may already know of. This game is a very well researched game. There are many historical troop types and landmarks. I can't even imagine how much time was put in to making this game as historically accurate as possible.Overall, this is a well-presented game.Now let's look at gameplay. This games battle system is hands down the best I have seen in any RTS ever. The attention to detail is astounding. Certain troops counter others, this is in other games. However, different formations and tactics can turn the tables on your so-called counters. You can be a regular Cesar if you play your cards right. The AI is not the sharpest tool in the shed, especially when it comes to troop movement. I have missed a table-turning oppurtunity in many a battle due to a units slow response or incorrect followthrough of an order. It could be said that this makes the game more realistic, but that doesn't make it any less frustrating. The game can be played in single or multiplayer player mode. Single player has three functions: Campaign, Custom battles, and Historical battles. The Campaign can be played as one of the three Roman factions at first and later other factions. Not every faction can be played as-at least not in th vanilla-which is a shame as many unique factions were left out. The campaign takes place over a world map as you and the other factions take turns building and managing an empire. The campaign is extremely immersive. Players personalities are reflected in how they play the game. I can be impatient, but I also am a procrastinator. As a result, I would impatiently blitz one enemy, then stand around repelling the attacks of another. The goals of the game are dependent on what type of campaign tou chose. A short one has small goals while a long one has large. Overall the campaign is the best part of the game. The custom battle option is fun for experimenting with new tactics or just goofing around. It is not something you will spend a ton of time on though. The Historical battles are just that, battles from history. They put you in the shoes of real ancient commanders in battles that actually took place. They're fun, but not very replayable. The multiplayer is the second best function of the game. It allows you to play online in battles with other players. The type of battles vary, from sieges to free-for-alls. There are even some historical battles exclusive to multiplayer. Overall, the multiplayer is great for when you want a change of pace.Over all, this game has a good presentation, pays attention to detail, and is highly immersive, the best ten bucks you'll ever spend. 9.5/10
